subchapter.p: According to phpframeworks.com, there are some areas needed to be taken into consideration when choosing a suitable PHP framework for product development.
Here you can see what features you take when choosing Phoebius.
Our goal is to provide a tool for domain manipulation, which can be easily integrated with contiguous technologies.

subchapter.title: PHP version
subchapter.p: Phoebius runs at PHP 5.2 or higher.

subchapter.title: ORM
subchapter.p:
Object-relational mapping is the most notable feature of Phoebius and it supports:
XML entity definition and mapping
code generation
one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many and composite associations
complex types
...and much more

subchapter.title: Multiple DB’s
subchapter.p: A database abstraction layer is implemented to support even any RDBMS as an entity storage. PostgreSQL and MySQL are now implemented.

subchapter.title: DB Objects
subchapter.p: A table gateway is an ORM feature that allows the developer to define a custom storage for any entity and query them transparently through the unified data access interface.

subchapter.title: MVC
subchapter.p: Phoebius provides a feature-reach MVC stack which is similar to modern ASP.NET MVC.

subchapter.title: Templates
subchapter.p: We believe that the best template engine is PHP itself. Thus Phoebius provides an infrastructure to create templates in pure PHP using the environment which is similar to ASP.NET templates.

subchapter.title: Caching
subchapter.p: Caching is not currently implemented, but it is planned to be provided in future versions as it is easy to integrate it in the existing solution as a separate layer.

subchapter.title: Ajax
subchapter.p: Ajax integration is currently not supported.

subchapter.title: Auth module
subchapter.p: Auth module is not yet implemented, but will be presented in future versions as a separate library or controller extension.

subchapter.title: Module support
subchapter.p: Module support has no sense in Phoebius, because Phoebius is not a CMS but a framework, whose applications may use even any PHP library.

subchapter.title: Event-driven development and AOP
subchapter.p: Event-driven development forces strongly-coupled interfaces and a code mess, so we won't support it.
